Mike has the poster to remind him of that day as he seems to replay it over and over each night. Mike seems to be trying to remember things, possibly clues as to who took his brother/ what happened to his brother. He constantly replays that day,  haunted by the incident, guilty that his brother was taken and that he couldn't help save him. So this does make it seem unlikely that Nebraska is where Garrett was kidnapped ( though it could still be a place they frequented as kids.) Matt, Iâ€™m 99% certain that the â€œNebraskaâ€ poster is a â€œBruce Springsteen Nebraska Concert Tourâ€ poster. Itâ€™s the same font & kerning, roughly the same colour scheme (given the lighting, itâ€™s tough to tell), and the right layout (Springsteenâ€™s name at the top, b&w photo in the middle, â€˜Nebraskaâ€™ on the bottom).  The song is a first-person retelling of the real-life story of Charlie Starkweather and his 14-year old girlfriend, Caril Ann Fugate. Starkweather was an executed spree killer, and Fugate, depending on which account you believe, was his hostage or his accomplice (a â€˜Stockholm Syndromeâ€™ scenario).

I have followed you and the FNAF series since DAY 1, and I LOVED it...but that's just it, I loved it. I saw the movie, and I loved it...but after trying so hard to piece all of the pieces together, I just can't. This universe started out as a fun, spoopy, heart attack wrenching series, but now....now it's just too much. Mike is William, but then there's Garrett, and Danny, and NO ONE knows each other...but they're all related, but they all died forever ago, but they didn't cause now they robots, but they don't know they are, and my brain is smoking in error just trying to make sense of it all. It doesn't. It MAKES NO SENSE WHAT SO EVER. It's like Afton is as powerful as Vorhees or Meyers, and I couldn't stand those asinine, pedantic, trivial movies either. I'm all down for creativity and imagination...but the laws of physics still gotta apply to that universe too, and it just doesn't seem to. Death is final. That's it. The End. Game Over. Making all these psychos be immortal in a way just doesn't work, and it's not gonna just cause you say it can. Once all these guys dead, they can't come back...yet they do...over and over and over. I can't. I'm done. I'm sorry Scott, I'm sorry MatPat, I'm sorry FNAF-heads. But I'm out. Peace!

Just wanted to put this theory here since the movie has come out and me and my girlfriend have been theorizing over it like hawks  (Spoilers if you havent watched the movie!!)       A detail that was brought by my girlfriend while we watched the movie was the balloon boy that appeared around the movie. The doll is obviously super natural, as we see it move around the establishment, in the office, the closet, and the taxi at the ending credits scene. We made a few connections and timeline jumps based on the games (even tho the movie universe and the games are different, we just thought we'd piece things together.) and we figured that the reason it moved around was because it was possessed but not by any of the kids, since they're obviously possessing the animatronics. And since there's only one person that's assumed dead during the movie, which is Garret, Mike's brother. Since FNAF 2 is a prequel, we figured that the time he dissapeared is around the time the old establishment before the opening of the new establishment in FNAF 1. That would explain why Balloon Boy moves around, and what happened to Garret in the first place.   Just a thought.

I love that you have mandatory fun nights. My team has a weekly mandatory appointment on Fridays called "What's Up - Extreme Friday Edition". It starts at 2pm and goes to 3pm, which coincides with the earliest time at which you can clock out for the weekend. What do we do in said meeting? We play board games. Werewolf, Concept, Happy Salmon, Codenames and stuff like that. I even managed to convince my director to buy us an additional storage unit for games by reasoning that this was a regular team bonding event. It helps that my team consists of massive nerds who are super happy to try out weird board games or TTRPGs on the fly. :3

You should consider this Film Theory: The Incredible Lie! Violet is now the child of Mr and Mrs Incredible as she has no physical traits that relate to them and her powers don't even seem to match or relate unlike Dash's, in fact she might be the child of Edna Mode whom the Incredibles took in after Violet's father died and Edna decided she didn't want to be a mother in her grief. Second part to the theory, Jack Jack isn't their child either and instead is the result of the government's secret project to mass produce Supers. With Supers not being all that numerous and potentially the birth rate between Supers being low, the government decided to make their own and thus experimented with orphans, giving them DNA of multiple Supers in hopes to replicate their powers if not create new powers, however with results not being as they wished and the ban on Supers the program got shut down, Jack Jack being one of these babies makes a lot of sense as it would explain the multiple powers he seems to have as well as why the Incredibles were insistent that Jack Jack had no powers, because the government ruled him a failed experiment and sent him to a Super Family in order to cover up what actually happened.  I know this theory sounds really out there but the more I think about it the more it makes sense and I'd love it if you could look into this more and see if there are any details I'm missing that can further support this theory or put it to rest.

If Mike Schmidt's real name being Mike Afton is canon is also canon in the movie, then we can also assume the following about the movie: Mike is William Afton's son. Matthew Lilliard has already been credited as William Afton and NOT Steve Raglan - the name we see him using in the trailer.  Mike has a twin/younger brother who was kidnapped at around age 5-8 (approx) and it's assumed that Afton is responsible for this, then Afton kidnapped his own son. Assuming Mike's brother was age 5-8 when kidnapped and was Mike's twin/younger brother, then that would put Mike at the same age frame at the time of his disappearance.  "Mike's dad" is played by another male actor who looks quite a bit younger than Matthew Lilliard and there is also a credit for "Young Mike" so I assume we see part of the flashback surrounding Mike's brother's disappearance through the eyes of Young Mike but also see a younger Mike's Dad in this scene, explaining why there are two different actors for the roles. Mike's parents are not present and I would guess they haven't been for quite some time now.  If Steve Raglan is actually William Afton like we assume and Afton is Mike's dad, we would assume Mike would recognise his dad, right? I think that after Afton kidnaps Mike's brother aka his own son, he goes under the radar and disappears from the family's life to avoid any suspicion that he was responsible. Mike was still only a young child himself when this incident happened and now appears to be in his mid-late twenties, so he may not remember much about his father in the first place if he also disappeared since the kidnapping which would explain why he does not recognise his father when he first meets him in his office as Steve Raglan.  I think part of the big finale in either this movie or the trilogy of movies in and of itself will be Mike discovering who Afton really is and that's how his inevitable hero arc grows throughout the trilogy.

As a long time fan of matpats FNAF theories, I have to say this is the first one I flat out disagree with. No disrespect though! Enjoyed watching it! I just think the movie (like the books) isn't going to be as cohesive as this and is going to create more questions than answers. I think it's possible we've been acting under the wrong assumption and Mike Schmidt isn't related to Afton or I think we might be looking at robot people again. I'm unconvinced about the blank ghost kid being the cupcake and I think we are focusing on the wrong kid. His face is clearly visible in the first trailer at least but there's another kid whos obscured, the one everyone's connecting to Freddy. I think the visible blank kid is regular Freddy and the obscured one is golden Freddy. What that means for the franchise, idk. But I think if there's anything to learn from this series, it's that no one FNAF entry can stand alone. It's gonna give us a lot of dangling threads that maybe line up in other parts of the franchise and it'll complete it's own narrative that probably won't feel satisfying. But again, no disrespect and I'm probably wrong too.
